forumNotes.content:
> DO NOT Format Flash Disk with FAT32 formatting (Windows XP  
> Default formatting) it will damaged Flash Disk and caused it to be unstable. Please use only FAT (or FAT16) formatting or Format from your utilities drivers

[http://www.scribd.co...bank-Controller](http://www.scribd.com/doc/24658435/Quick-Start-Guide-for-Flash-Disk-Chipsbank-Controller "External link")  

Can someone explain why a different type of formatting could make some UFDs "unstable"?  

I experienced something like that when I did zero-out an entire Chipsbank CBM2091 UFD and then restored its disk image. The UFD had worked fine initially but then started to play up on another computer. It was full of sector-read errors. The problem was fixed after low-level format with an UMPtool.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: Absolutely no idea! There is an argument that NTFS might lead to wearing of cells but FAT16 and FAT32 are fine. After all, most manufacturers format as FAT32 when the USB sticks leave the factory.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
That document is seemingly dated November 2005.  
It is very likely that it is obsolete and contains info no longer appliable.  

There is no particular difference - in the sense of different way of working of the filesystem - between FAT16 and FAT32.  

The only - very "light" possible explanantion may be something in the FORMAT command of XP and the way it accesses the disk. (but I cannot see how this will influence stability)  

Of course NTFS is another thing.
